II. 

THE MACROECONOMIC, SOCIAL, AND GOVERNANCE CONTEXT 

A. 

Macroeconomic Developments 

2. 
Ten  years  after  the  Asian  financial  crisis  and  domestic  political  turmoil,  Indonesia  has 
emerged economically stronger, more democratic, and increasingly resilient to both internal and 
external  shocks.  In  the  past  5  years  in  particular,  the  country  has  performed  impressively  in 
terms  of  macroeconomic  management  and  political  stability  has  become  more  entrenched,  as 
the  democratic  process  has  deepened  and  achieved  wider  acceptance.  Progressively  higher 
gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth  has  led  since  2005  to  per  capita  real  GDP  exceeding 
precrisis  levels.  Prudent  macroeconomic  management  has  resulted  in  lower  budget  deficits,  a 
much  lower  debt–GDP  ratio,  and  manageable  inflation,  until  recently.  The  financial sector  has 
largely  recovered  from  the  1998  crisis  and  market  sentiment  appears  largely  positive.  Exports 
are  at  record  levels,  the  balance  of  payments  position  is  strong,  and  foreign  reserves  are  at 
historic  highs.  In  addition,  investment,  while  still  low  by  historical  standards,  is  rising  fast. 
Despite the current global economic slowdown, real GDP accelerated to a 10-year high of 6.3% 
in  2007.  However,  recent  growth  has  not  translated  into  commensurate  increases  in 
employment and reductions in poverty, and nearly half of the population remains vulnerable to 
poverty. The challenge is to build on the foundations of macroeconomic and social stability; and 
accelerate growth to reduce unemployment, poverty, and overall levels of vulnerability.  
 
3. 
To  achieve  these  objectives,  the  Government  is  pursuing  a  pro-growth  agenda  while 
pushing  forward  on  broad  structural  and  institutional  reforms.  Progress  has  been  made  on  all 
fronts, albeit unevenly in some areas. Despite recent improvements, there is a continued need 
to  improve  the  investment  climate,  public  financial  management,  and  service  delivery 
mechanisms  to  the  poor.  The  DPSP  series  has  allowed  the  Government  to  work  with 
development partners in a flexible manner to implement critical high-level macroeconomic and 
crosscutting  sector  reforms  that  address  constraints  to  growth  and  poverty  reduction  while 
providing predictability of financial support. As such, its coverage is fairly broad. Governance is 
a recurring theme throughout the DPSP series, as it aims to promote transparency in all its core 
policy areas. The proposed DPSP-4 is anchored in the country strategy and program (CSP) of 
the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB), 1  which  in  turn  provides  for  deeper  sector-level 
interventions  to  complement  the  macroeconomic  and  governance  reforms  supported  through 
the  DPSP  series.  The  DPSP-4  builds  on  past  DPSP  operations  to  support  the  Government 
further  on  key  reform  measures  in  the  core  areas  of  investment  climate,  public  financial 
management and anticorruption, and service delivery to the poor.  
 
4. 
Indonesia’s  growth  performance  has 
remained strong, despite a deteriorating global environment. Having recorded its highest growth 
rate in a decade of 6.3% in 2007, the growth momentum was sustained at 6.4% during the first 
semester of 2008. The main drivers of growth were private consumption, and gross fixed capital 
formation,  including  a  sharp  rise  in foreign  direct  investment.  While  still  below  precrisis  levels,

6. 
Like its neighbors, Indonesia’s inflation has risen sharply since the beginning of the year, 
to  11.8%  year-on-year  in  October  2008.  While  much  of  the  increase  in  inflation  has  been 
attributed  to  higher  food  prices2 (food  items  accounting  for  nearly  40%  of  the  consumer  price 
index),  a  28.7%  increase  in  administered  fuel  prices  in  late  May  2008  added  to  subsequent 
inflationary pressures both directly and indirectly through generalized price setting. To address 
such pressures, Bank Indonesia has gradually tightened monetary policy by a series of 25 basis 
point increases in interest rates that have led to its policy rate increasing from 8.0% in May 2008 
to 9.5% in October 2008. 
 
7. 
Indonesia’s  fiscal  performance  has  remained  strong  despite  pressure  from  increasing 
energy subsidies. Energy (fuel and electricity) subsidies rose to 3% of GDP in 2007. The fiscal 
deficit was, however, contained at 1.3% of GDP, slightly below the deficit of 1.5% projected in 
the revised budget. Energy subsidies increased sharply in 2008 as the oil price assumption in 
the budget was raised from an original $60 to $95, and then again to $110 per barrel. After oil 
prices passed the $110 per barrel threshold, the Government raised regulated fuel prices by an 
average  of  28.7%  in  late  May.  It  is  applying  part  of  the  saving  to  fund  an  unconditional  cash 
transfer  that  offsets  rising  food  costs  for  70  million  of  the  country’s  poor  and  near-poor.  The 
Government  is  using  most  of  the  remainder  to  reduce  this  year’s  budget  deficit.  The  oil  price 
hike  in  May,  combined  with  the  recent  decline  in  international  oil  prices,  has  helped  contain 
energy  subsidies  in  2008.  Most  of  these  subsidies  are  highly  regressive—the  richest  fifth  of 
households directly receive as much as two-thirds of Indonesia’s fuel subsidy. Higher levels of 
fossil  fuel  subsidies  also  create  a  disincentive  to  invest  in  renewable  sources  of  energy  and 
energy efficiency measures, producing a detrimental impact on the environment. A few selected 
food  and  agriculture  items  are  also  subsidized,  but  such  outlays  account  for  a  relatively  small 
share of total subsides. The real cost of the subsidies is the lost opportunity to invest increased

The global economic turmoil has had a significant impact on Indonesia. The structure of 
Indonesia’s financial sector and exports would have, however, suggested that the country was 
better equipped than some of its neighbors to confront the current downturn. The banking sector 
had limited direct exposure to developments in the United States financial markets, low reliance 
on  external  financing,  and  had  low  levels  of  nonperforming  loans  (3.4%)  and  high  capital 
adequacy  ratios  (17.1%)  in  August  2008.  Indonesia’s  trade  share  at  50%  of  GDP  is  also 
relatively  small,  while  the  structure  and  destination  of  its  exports  potentially  offered  some 
protection  to  its  external  sector  from  the  global  slowdown.  Almost  two-thirds  of  Indonesia’s 
exports are commodities, whose prices had remained strong for much of the year. Indonesia’s 
exports have also been increasingly moving toward economies in Asia and away from the US 
(12.3% of total exports in 2007) and European Union (14.5% of total exports in 2007). However, 
export  growth  has  moderated  in  recent  months  as  commodity  prices  have  weakened  and  the 
global economic outlook has deteriorated.  Domestic capital markets have also been subject to 
periodic bouts of volatility since the beginning of 2008, and capital flight since October 2008. By 
the end of September 2008, the Indonesian stock exchange had fallen by 33% since the start of 
the  year,  and  by  7  November  the  stock  exchange  had  fallen  by  a  further  27%  from  end-
September levels. A lower risk appetite for emerging market debt, higher domestic inflation, and 
tighter  credit  markets  have  adversely  affected  sentiment,  with  spreads  on  Indonesian  5-year 
credit default swaps increasing from 352.7 on 1 October 2008 to 1,256.7 on 23 October 2008, 
before  moderating  to  620.8  on  7  November  2008.  These  developments  have  impacted 
negatively  on  government  debt  markets,  with  yields  on  government  bonds  having  risen  on 
average  by  1,021  basis  points  by  end-October,  before  moderating  to  609  basis  points  by  7 
November  2008.  The  rupiah,  which  had  remained  broadly  stable  against  the  US  dollar  during 
the  first  9  months  of  2008  has,  however,  continued  to  decline  since  end-September  and  has 
depreciated by 18% as of 7 November 2008. 
 
10. 
GDP  growth  is  expected  to  moderate  to  6.1%  in  2008  and  5.2%  in  2009,  as  export 
growth  and  foreign  direct  investment  slows  with  the  global  economic  downturn  (Table  3). 
Growth  during  this  period  will  be  sustained  by  domestic  consumption  demand.  However,  the 
possibility  of  a  prolonged  and  more  severe  slump  in  the  global  economy  holds  considerable 
downside  risks  to  Indonesia.  A  sharper  slowdown  in  the  global  economy  and  continued 
turbulence in international financial markets would further affect demand for Indonesian exports 
and limit investment growth as credit markets tighten. Tighter credit markets and increased risk 
aversion could also limit the Government’s ability to tap international financial markets. This has

Indonesia’s poverty rate, measured with reference to the national poverty line, fell from 16.6% in 
March  2007  to  15.4%  in  March  2008.  The  decrease  resumed  the  trend  of  gradually  declining 
poverty  rates  since  2000,  which  had  been  interrupted  in  2006  by  a  nearly  2 percentage  point 
increase caused by a sharp rise in rice prices. Both urban and rural poverty declined over the 
course  of  2007;  the  decline  was  spatially  quite  uniform,  with  even  the  poorest  provinces 
registering decreases in their poverty rates. These levels of poverty, however, translate to about 
35 million poor people, while nearly half the population could be considered among the poor or 
near-poor  because  their  per  capita  consumption  levels  were  less  than  one-third  above  the 
national  poverty  line.  These  figures  suggest  that  there  is  a  very  large  group  of  near-poor  in 
Indonesia who are highly vulnerable to shocks at all levels. The poverty profile in Indonesia still 
indicates  considerable  regional  differences  in  poverty—nine  provinces  have  poverty  rates  of 
less than 10% (4.3% in Jakarta) while 10 provinces have poverty rates of more than 20% (37%

in Papua). A challenge for the Government is that, while the poverty incidence is far higher in 
eastern  regions,  most  of  Indonesia’s  poor  live  in  the  densely  populated  and  relatively  more 
prosperous western  regions.  Indonesia’s  labor  market  may  also  be  turning  the  corner  and  the 
phenomenon  of  “jobless  growth”  may  be  easing.  The  employment  numbers  from  the  latest 
(February  2008)  national  labor  force  survey  indicate  improvements  in  many  labor  market 
outcomes, continuing what appears now to be an improving trend since 2005. The employment 
rate,  the  share  of  the  labor  force  with  nonfarm  employment,  as  well  as  the  share  with  formal 
jobs  have  all  been  rising,  while  the  open  unemployment  rate  has  fallen  to  8.5%  in  February 
2008 from 9.8% a year earlier.

Non-Income  Millennium  Development  Goals.  Indonesia’s  progress  toward  meeting 
other Millennium Development Goal (MDG) targets is somewhat mixed. Malnutrition remains a 
significant  public  health  problem,  with  the  percentage  of  children  under  5  years  who  are 
underweight  rising  from  24.6%  in  2000  to  28.0%  in  2005.  This  has  been  attributed  in  part  to 
decentralization  in  2000,  since  the  responsibilities  for  the  previous  highly  centralized  family 
nutrition programs were devolved to more than 400 districts. This created difficulties in planning, 
financing, and supervising these programs. On the MDG goal relating to education, Indonesia is 
well on track to achieve the target in primary net enrollment, but it is falling behind in achieving 
net  enrollment  in  lower  secondary  education.  In  relation  to  the  MDG  on  gender  equality, 
Indonesia is on track to achieve gender equality in education. The gender gaps in terms of net 
enrollment  rates  in  primary  and  lower  secondary  education  have  already  been  closed. 
Measured  in  terms  of  labor  market  participation  in  the  nonagricultural  sector  and  seats  in 
Parliament, however, participation of women continues to lag behind that of men. Indonesia is 
also on track to achieve the MDG target of reducing the under-5 mortality rate by two-thirds by 
2015, but progress in reducing the maternal mortality ratio has not been sufficient to meet the 
levels  targeted  in  the  MDGs.  While  the  country  remains  on  track  for  achieving  the  targets  for 
improved drinking water, it is off track with regard to attaining the target on access to improved 
sanitation facilities. The country is severely off track in achieving the targets of reversing forestry 
loss.  In  most  of  the  MDG-related  indicators,  sharp  regional  and  socioeconomic  differentials 
remain and progress in many instances remains less than has been achieved by the relatively 
more advanced economies of Southeast Asia.

18.

3 (approved in December 2007), the proposed DPSP-4 will provide parallel cofinancing support

The Evolution of the Program 

23. 
At its inception in 2004, the DPL series was designed to support Indonesia’s transition 
from postcrisis stabilization to more long-term development. The DPL was expected to provide 
the foundation for continued, medium-term policy engagement in the areas of macroeconomic 
stability,  the  investment  climate,  and  public  financial  management  and  anticorruption.  It  also 
provided for a flexible means of taking into account the pace and fluidity of the reform process. 
Hence, as the program has evolved, the scope of the reform agenda has become broader. The 
broadening  of  the  agenda  has  also  been  accompanied  by  a  deepening  of  reforms,  whereby 
successive DPL operations have built on previous ones to ensure incremental implementation. 
The  theme  of  the  DPL-1  was  on  restoring  and  maintaining  macroeconomic  stability  and 
consolidating macroeconomic achievements at a time when Indonesia was leaving its postcrisis 
International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  program.  Within  this  context,  the  main  focus  was  on 
macroeconomic  stability  and  creditworthiness,

management  and  governance.  The  theme  of  the  DPL-2/DPSP-1  progressed  toward  creating 
fiscal  space.  This  led  to  themes  more  focused  on  implementation.  The  emphasis  of  the  DPL-
3/DPSP-2 was on utilizing the fiscal space that had been created in the DPL-2 to have a greater

51. 
After  the  adoption  of  a  new  regulatory  framework  of  2003-2004,  the  Government  is 
implementing  public  financial  management  reforms  as  legislated.  These  efforts  are  part  of  a 
broader agenda to improve governance and enhance service delivery, with the ultimate goal of 
sustained  economic  growth  and  poverty  alleviation.  Progress  has  been  achieved  in  the  way 
public  finances  are  managed  and  in  increasing  transparency  and  independent  oversight.  In 
particular,  progress  has  been  made  in  streamlining  the  budget  formulation  process  and 
documentation as articulated in new public financial management (PFM) laws. The Government 
is also beginning to address civil service reforms with a view to providing an enabling framework 
for  more  effective  public  institutions.  These  achievements  provide  a  firm  foundation  for  further 
progress,  but  significant  challenges  remain  across  the  public  financial  management  cycle 
including budget formulation, execution, and reporting and auditing. 
 
52. 
Although the budget preparation process is not yet compatible with a medium-term fiscal 
perspective,  progress  is  being  made  on  this  front.  There  has  been  some  progress  in  recent 
years in terms of aligning policy priorities to allocations in the budget. The DPL-4/DPSP-3 also 
supported the introduction of a medium-term macro fiscal framework in the 2008 budget, with a 
system  of  forward  estimates  for  two  out-years.  However,  budget  submissions  continue  to  be 
annual  and  there  is  no  framework  to  establish  credible  forward  estimates  that  are  reconciled 
with the projected resource envelope and other projections. To address this issue, the current 
program  supports  reforms  to  the  budget  preparation  process  by  revising  budget  templates  to 
give them a greater results orientation. Despite these efforts, the full development of a medium-
term  expenditure  framework  (MTEF)  can  realistically  only  be  achieved  in  the  medium  to  long 
term.  
 
53.  With regard to the budget execution process, a number of challenges remain pertaining 
to  cash  management,  processing,  accounting  and  reporting  of  both  revenue  and  expenditure 
transactions,  and  the  execution  of  capital  expenditures.  Progress  has  been  made  in  the 
development of a treasury single account (TSA) to strengthen cash management, but a number 
of accounts (e.g., salary accounts, revenue accounts) continue to hold idle cash balances and 
operational cash planning is at a very early stage of development. A chart of accounts broadly 
consistent  with  the  Government  Finance  Statistics  Manual  (GFSM) 2001  was  introduced  in 
2005,  enabling  codification  of  expenditures  across  multiple  dimensions  and  stages  of  the 
expenditure  management  cycle,  but  some  segments  such  as  the  activity  and  program  codes 
need  improvement.  The  Government  also  promulgated  Government  Accounting  Standards  in 
2005 that are being adhered to, and has made good progress in ensuring timely availability of 
annual  financial  statements  to  Parliament  and  to  the  public.  Additional  MOF  regulations  have 
put emphasis on ministers being responsible to record the budget allotment in their ministries; 
introduced  new  accounting  subsystems  at  the  treasury  accounting  system;  and  placed  more 
emphasis  on  receivables,  payables,  and  investment  recording  at  the  line  ministries.  However, 
there are problems in the application of the standards in the line ministries, and the systems and 
data  environment  for  processing  and  recording  of  transactions  is  fragmented  and  not  yet  fully 
automated—undermining and the accuracy and reliability of financial reporting. This has led the

Improving  delivery  of  public  services  continues  to  be  critical  for  Indonesia.  Lagging 
70. 
human development indicators—such as the high maternal mortality rate, malnutrition rate, and 
low  transition  from  primary  school  to  secondary  school—must  be  tackled  by  improving  the 
quality of services. This goes beyond levels of public spending. It is about knowing what works 
and what does not. It is about institutionalizing program assessment and linking the findings with 
planning  and  budget  allocations.  It  is  about  having  a  good  system  to  target  the  marginalized 
groups.  It  is  also  about  empowering  local  government,  community,  and  service  providers  to 
deliver quality services. 
 
71. 
Indonesia has recognized the importance of institutionalizing evaluation and assessment 
in  the  policy  formulation  and  budgetary  allocation  processes.  The  intent  is  to  promote  a  more 
adequate generation and systematic use of public performance information in decision making 
while  strengthening  effective  accountability,  within  the  Government,  service  providers,  and 
citizens.  This  is  a  complex  and  long-term  objective,  and  can  only  happen  by  strengthening 
capacities to produce reliable and timely performance information, and through the introduction 
of  sound  institutional  arrangements  to  ensure  that  monitoring  and  evaluation  is  properly 
integrated into the management cycle.

Over the past few years, the Government has launched several large-scale programs to 
improve  the  access  of  marginalized  groups  to  basic  services.  Improving  targeting  in  these 
programs remains an ongoing challenge. Historically, household targeting systems in Indonesia 
have not been particularly strong. Not only do all programs have sizeable under-coverage and 
leakage errors, programs also tend to have different targeting systems.

Implementation of the DPSP cluster is subject to the following risks:

External  vulnerabilities.  With  improvements  in  its  macroeconomic  indicators, 
Indonesia’s  resilience  to  external  shocks  has  increased.  Factors  limiting  the 
potential impacts of external shocks include diversity of exports, limited external 
debt  exposure,  and  an  adequate  level  of  reserves.  The  banking  sector  is  also 
now sufficiently strong to weather a moderate external shock. The maintenance 
of a financial sector safety net supported by the DPL/DPSP will help to improve 
the  resilience  of  the  banking  sector.  Nevertheless,  risks  remain  high,  especially 
during  a  period  of  global  financial  turmoil.  Indonesia  is  a  financially  open 
economy and there are significant foreign holdings, especially in the stock market 
and government bonds. Indonesia is thus vulnerable to sudden shifts in investor 
sentiment. If significant funds are pulled back because of liquidity demands in the 
US  and  elsewhere  and/or  increased  emerging  market  risk  aversion,  this  could 
lead to increased pressure on domestic interest and exchange rates. In addition, 
the  Government  has  large  gross  financing  needs  over  the  next  few  years,  and 
tighter  credit  markets  and  increased  risk  aversion  could  limit  the  Government’s 
ability to tap international financial markets. This could force the Government to 
cut budgetary outlays to maintain fiscal balance, with adverse consequences for 
infrastructure  and  social  expenditure.  Mitigating  these  risks  will  require  solid 
cooperation  between  Bank  Indonesia  and  the  economic  ministries  to  reassure

Core Policy Area 1: Macroeconomic Stability 

A. 
 
1. 
The  Development  Policy  Loan  (DPL)/Development  Policy  Support  Program  (DPSP) 
series  sought  to  improve  debt  management  and  fiscal  policy  management  by  reducing 
subsidies  to  the  nonpoor  and  making  revenue  administration  more  efficient  through  the 
expansion of modern tax officers. 
 
2. 
Overall  macroeconomic  fundamentals  remain  sound  and  fiscal  consolidation  has 
improved  with  the  expansion  of  the  tax  base  and  improved  efficiency.  Economic  growth 
averaged a substantive 5.6% during 2004–2007, the debt–gross domestic product (GDP) ratio 
declined nearly 25 percentage points, budget deficits have declined, and high reserves provide 
the  country  with  a  comfortable  liquidity  cushion.  Increasing  non-oil  and  gas  revenues  as  a 
percentage of GDP were supported by a prior DPL/DPSP action to expand modernization of tax 
offices  and  the  tax  base,  including  to  medium  and  small  taxpayers.  These  taxpayers  are  now 
responsible  for  the  largest  share  of  Indonesian  taxes.  Additional  reforms  to  improve  tax 
analysis, including the creation of a Tax Policy Office, are expected to generate improvements 
in revenue collection.  
 
3. 
On  the  expenditure  side,  reductions  in  non-targeted  fuel  subsidies  in  2005  allowed 
greater social spending but untargeted subsidies remain burdensome. In 2005, the Government 
raised fuel prices, resulting in the decline of fuel subsidies from 4% of GDP in 2004 to 2.7% in 
2007, freeing up $10 billion a year. This amount was rolled out into cash transfers targeted at 
the poor and also higher health and education expenditures. However, as oil prices continued to 
break  record  highs  throughout  2008,  fuel  subsidies  rose  sharply,  causing  the  Government  to 
spend  an  additional  Rp50  trillion  (1.2%  of  GDP)  in  the  first  part  of  the  year.  In  May 2008,  the 
Government  again  increased  fuel  prices  by  almost  30%  and  accompanied  this  with  a  widely 
publicized and improved cash transfer program. This move, together with the recent reduction in 
oil prices, has brought down the projected energy subsidy in 2008 to 4.7% of GDP, which still 
surpasses both central government capital and social spending by 1.7% of GDP. 

 
4. 
Rating  agencies  responded  favorably  to  Indonesia’s  lower  debt  ratio  and  reform 
packages. In a reflection of the country’s more sound economic footing, all three credit agencies 
have raised their credit ratings at least three notches since 2003. Standard and Poor’s upgraded 
Indonesia’s  credit  rating  from  CCC+  in  2003  to  BB–  by  2008;  likewise  in  this  period,  Moody’s 
raised its ratings from B2 to Ba3; and Fitch raised its from B to BB. In supporting their ratings 
upgrades, the agencies cited debt reduction as the primary cause, as well as the Government’s 
commitment  to  broad-based  reform,  including  changes  to  investment  laws,  customs  and  tax 
reforms,  and  fiscal  reforms,  specifically  in  treasury  and  budget—measures  supported  by  the 
DPL/DPSP series.

C. 
 
12. 
To  improve  the  efficiency,  transparency,  and  accountability  of  public  finances,  the 
DPL/DPSP  series  focused  on  three  key  areas  of  reform:  (i)  modernizing  public  financial 
management  systems,  (ii)  strengthening  institutional  reform  within  the  Ministry  of  Finance 
(MOF), and more recently (iii) civil service reform.  
 
13. 
Changes in the legal and regulatory architecture for public financial management (PFM) 
are now largely complete and the focus is on implementing a modern PFM system. Before the 
start  of  the  DPL/DPSP  series,  the  Government’s  financial  operations  were  based  on  outdated 
laws (from 1925) that had been updated with a series of inadequate decrees. The previous PFM 
system  allowed  for  systematic  and  pervasive  corruption,  collusion,  and  nepotism  because 
assignments  were  unclear,  transparency  was  low,  and  enforcement  poor.  Budget  formulation 
was opaque and inefficient, making it difficult to quantify basic concepts of the budget. Budget 
execution was often delayed and monitoring arrangements were weak. Procurement processes 
were  prone  to  corruption  and  collusion.  Accounting  and  reporting  were  fragmented  and  not 
always  reliable,  and  mandates  of  government  audit  bodies  were  not  clearly  defined.  The  DPL 
supported  various  regulatory  measures  needed  to  create the  regulatory  framework  for  a  more 
modern PFM system, in the areas of budget preparation and execution.  
 
14. 
A  key  achievement  under  the  DPL/DPSP  has  been  the  implementation  of  the  treasury 
single account (TSA) to improve cash management of public finances. At the start of the DPL 
series,  more  than  18,000  commercial  bank  accounts—and  other  accounts  not  even  known  to 
the  Treasury—handled  government  funds.  As  an  initial  step,  the  DPL-1  supported  addressing 
the  regulatory  deficiencies  in  the  PFM  system,  including  the  passage  of  several  laws  defining 
the regulatory framework. Reorganization of MOF was also carried out to begin the process of 
establishing a TSA, and to clean up the cash management issues the Government faced. The 
DPL-2/DPSP-1  then  supported  the  implementing  regulations  underlining  these  laws  and 
adopted an implementation plan. The DPL-3/DPSP-2 pilot tested the TSA to have zero-balance 
accounts in over 50 provincial treasury offices (KPPNs). The DPL-4/DPSP-3 extended the TSA 
coverage  to  nearly  full  implementation  on  government  expenditure  accounts.  Although  there 
were some timing issues (e.g., training for local agencies to implement the TSA came after the 
requirement to do so), the push to meet the deadline of the DPL accelerated implementation of 
the  TSA.  Progress  on  covering  revenue  accounts  has  been  more  complicated,  but  has 
commenced.

Prior  to  the  2005  fuel  prices  rise,  Indonesia’s  social  protection  system  was  characterized  by 
emergency  short-term  safety  net  programs  and  price  subsidies.  The  country’s  three  targeted

fuel  price  hike  made  available  more  funds  for  social  spending,  the  DPL  supported  building

these released funds. The 2005 fuel hike was accompanied by a new cash transfer program to 
help  alleviate  the  impact  on  the  poorest  households—representing  a substantial shift  from  the 
ineffective and inefficient general subsidy program. Evaluative assessments were conducted to 
improve  targeting  and  performance  of  the  cash  transfer  program,  and  the  lessons  were 
incorporated  into  the  new  cash  transfer  program  that  accompanied  the  May  2008  fuel  price 
increase.  The  Government  has  undertaken  significant  steps  to  set  up  an  effective  and 
comprehensive  monitoring  and  evaluation  function,  including  the  establishment  of  a  unit  to

implementation  of  the  overall  expenditure  program,  require  lengthy  revision,  sometimes 
involving Parliament. Such inflexibility creates practical difficulties and inefficiencies.

I. 

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A. Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 

The  National  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy  (NPRS)  has  five  basic  strategies  for  poverty  reduction:  (i)  broadening 
opportunities, (ii) empowering community institutions, (iii) increasing capacity, (iv) providing social protection, and 
(v) promoting global partnerships. The NPRS is to be implemented through macroeconomic strategy and policies 
for  fulfilling  basic  rights,  promoting  gender  justice  and  equality,  and  regional  development.  It  considers 
macroeconomic policies  as the foundation for reducing poverty through  a supportive  business environment and 
broad  opportunities  for  increasing  the  capability  of  the  poor  through  four  related  objectives:  (i)  create 
macroeconomic  stability,  (ii)  promote  economic  growth,  (iii) increase  opportunities  for  employment  and 
entrepreneurship,  and  (iv)  reduce  inequalities  between  regions.  The  Government’s  medium-term  national 
development  plan  (RPJM)  includes  the  main  tenets  of  the  previous  draft  NPRS  and  incorporates  the  eight 
Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs).  This  provides  an  overarching  framework  that  places  human 
development and poverty reduction at the center of the development agenda. 
 
The country poverty assessmenta and country poverty partnership agreementb consider macroeconomic stability 
as a fundamental underpinning to poverty reduction. Under the agreement, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
has  agreed  to  support  the  Government  in  promoting  macroeconomic  stability  for  inclusive  growth  and  poverty 
reduction. The highest priority is given to institutional reforms to achieve transparent and accountable institutions. 
The  poverty  agreement  also  calls  for  expanding  and  improving  such  key  basic  services  as  health,  education, 
water supply, and sanitation through public–private partnerships; and points out the need to expand the system of 
social protection.

The majority of triggers under these core policy areas concern policy areas that do not directly affect the household 
budgets of the poor. The links between poverty reduction and areas such as tax and customs reforms, regulatory 
reforms to improve the investment climate, nonbank financial sector deepening, and strengthening budget planning 
and execution, and transparency in financial management are indirect—through increased economic growth and a 
more efficient allocation of resources.  
 
Two  triggers  in  the  DPSP-4  policy  matrix  on  tariff  harmonization  and  improved  access  of  finance  for  small  and 
medium-sized  enterprises  (SME)  are  likely  to  affect  the  poor  in  a  more  direct  manner.  Firstly,  changes  in  tariff 
rates  can  alter  the  purchasing  power  of  poor  households.  Tariff  reductions  in  goods  that  make  up  a  significant 
share of poor households’ budgets will benefit the poor by increasing their purchasing power. To mitigate risks of 
adverse  affects  in  low-income  groups,  the  additional  research  capacity  mandated  by  the  trigger  should  enable 
policymakers to use empirical estimates of the impact of tariff adjustments on poor households as an input into 
the policy process. Secondly, improved SME access to finance is likely to have a direct multiplier impact on rural 
incomes, employment generation, and poverty reduction. A further set of triggers on strengthening effective and 
pro-poor  targeting  of  public  programs,  and  community-driven  development  will  have  unambiguously  beneficial
